notes: Marta Coll and colleagues’ 2010 Mediterranean Sea biodiversity census reported approximately 17,000 species, nearly double the number reported in Carlo Bianchi and Carla Morri’s 2000 census—a difference only partly attributable to the description of new invertebrate species...
student_goal: Determine the logical conclusion based on contrasting biodiversity census results and researcher methodology.

answer_choices.A: Coll and colleagues reported a much higher number of species than Bianchi and Morri did largely due to the inclusion of invertebrate species that had not been described at the time of Bianchi and Morri’s census.
answer_choices.B: some differences observed in microorganisms may have been treated as variations within species by Bianchi and Morri but treated as indicative of distinct species by Coll and colleagues.
answer_choices.C: Bianchi and Morri may have been less sensitive to the degree of morphological variation displayed within a typical species of microorganism than Coll and colleagues were.
answer_choices.D: the absence of clarity regarding how to differentiate among species of microorganisms may have resulted in Coll and colleagues underestimating the number of microorganism species.

notes: In her 2021 article “Throwaway History: Towards a Historiography of Ephemera,” Anne Garner discusses John Johnson, a collector of items intended to be discarded. His collection was initially viewed as worthless but later acquired by Oxford’s Bodleian Library in 1968 due to its historical value.
student_goal: Determine what Johnson’s example suggests about changing scholarly attitudes.

answer_choices.A: demonstrate the difficulties faced by contemporary historians in conducting research at the Bodleian Library without access to ephemera.
answer_choices.B: represent the challenge of incorporating examples of ephemera into the collections of libraries and other scholarly institutions.
answer_choices.C: lend support to arguments by historians and other researchers who continue to assert that ephemera holds no value for scholars.
answer_choices.D: illustrate both the relatively low scholarly regard in which ephemera was once held and the later recognition of ephemera’s possible utility.

notes: Researchers examined how interruptions affect people’s enjoyment of experiences. They found that interruptions can increase enjoyment of pleasant experiences and hypothesized the opposite for unpleasant ones. In a study, participants listened to construction noise interrupted by silence breaks or not.
student_goal: Infer researchers’ expectations for the effect of interruptions on unpleasant experiences.

answer_choices.A: find the disruptions more irritating as time went on.
answer_choices.B: rate the listening experience as more negative than those whose listening experience was uninterrupted.
answer_choices.C: rate the experience of listening to construction noise as lasting for less time than it actually lasted.
answer_choices.D: perceive the volume of the construction noise as growing softer over time.

notes: Shakespeare’s tragedies are widely appreciated today for their broad themes, but understanding his history plays requires deep knowledge of English history. Romeo and Juliet remains accessible due to its universal themes.
student_goal: Compare the accessibility of Shakespeare’s tragedies and history plays to modern audiences.

answer_choices.A: many theatergoers and readers today are likely to find Shakespeare’s history plays less engaging than the tragedies.
answer_choices.B: some of Shakespeare’s tragedies are more relevant to today’s audiences than twentieth-century plays.
answer_choices.C: Romeo and Juliet is the most thematically accessible of all Shakespeare’s tragedies.
answer_choices.D: experts in English history tend to prefer Shakespeare’s history plays to his other works.

notes: In the 1800s, Euro-American farmers in the northeastern U.S. used farming techniques similar to those of the Haudenosaunee, despite not having direct contact with Haudenosaunee farms. This suggests indirect transmission of knowledge.
student_goal: Determine the most logical explanation for how Euro-American farmers adopted Haudenosaunee techniques.

answer_choices.A: those farmers learned the techniques from other people who were more directly influenced by Haudenosaunee practices.
answer_choices.B: the crops typically cultivated by Euro-American farmers in the northeastern United States were not well suited to Haudenosaunee farming techniques.
answer_choices.C: Haudenosaunee farming techniques were widely used in regions outside the northeastern United States.
answer_choices.D: Euro-American farmers only began to recognize the benefits of Haudenosaunee farming techniques late in the nineteenth century.

notes: A management research team found that workplace interruptions, though commonly viewed as reducing productivity, can increase employees’ sense of belonging and satisfaction.
student_goal: Assess the implications of research findings about workplace interruptions.

answer_choices.A: the interpersonal benefits of some interruptions in the workplace may offset the perceived negative effects.
answer_choices.B: in order to maximize productivity, employers should be willing to interrupt employees frequently throughout the day.
answer_choices.C: most employees avoid interrupting colleagues because they don’t appreciate being interrupted themselves.
answer_choices.D: in order to cultivate an ideal workplace environment, interruptions of work should be discouraged.

notes: Polynesians cultivated sweet potatoes before any known contact with South America. DNA evidence shows the varieties in Polynesia diverged from South American types over 100,000 years ago—long before humans settled Polynesia.
student_goal: Determine the most plausible conclusion about how sweet potatoes arrived in Polynesia.

answer_choices.A: the cultivation of the sweet potato in Polynesia likely predates its cultivation in South America.
answer_choices.B: Polynesian peoples likely acquired the sweet potato from South American peoples only within the last three thousand years.
answer_choices.C: human activity likely played no role in the introduction of the sweet potato in Polynesia.
answer_choices.D: Polynesian sweet potato varieties likely descend from a single South American variety that was domesticated, not wild.

notes: Ecologists studied methane emissions in tanks with different aquatic plants. Tanks with underwater plants like watermilfoil released less methane than tanks with surface plants like duckweed or algae.
student_goal: Determine the environmental impact of different types of aquatic vegetation.

answer_choices.A: the presence of some kinds of underwater plants like watermilfoil helps prevent methane from escaping shallow lakes and ponds.
answer_choices.B: shallow lakes and ponds release more methane than deeper bodies of water because shallow bodies of water usually have more plants than deep bodies of water do.
answer_choices.C: shallow lakes and ponds are more likely to contain algae than to contain either watermilfoil or duckweed.
answer_choices.D: having a mix of algae, underwater plants, and floating plants is the best way to reduce the amount of methane in shallow lakes and ponds.

notes: Zelda Fitzgerald, while often viewed as an influence on her husband F. Scott Fitzgerald’s writing, also authored her own significant works. Scholars frequently overlook her literary contributions.
student_goal: Assess how scholarly views of Zelda Fitzgerald may misrepresent her legacy.

answer_choices.A: overlook the many other factors that motivated F. Scott to write.
answer_choices.B: risk misrepresenting the full range of Zelda’s contributions to literature.
answer_choices.C: may draw inaccurate conclusions about how F. Scott and Zelda viewed each other’s works.
answer_choices.D: tend to read the works of F. Scott and Zelda in an overly autobiographical light.

notes: Musicians have tried the 'pay as you wish' pricing model. One band earned less than expected, while another artist earned more than expected using the same model.
student_goal: Evaluate the variability in financial success of the 'pay as you wish' pricing strategy.

answer_choices.A: prove financially successful for some musicians but disappointing for others.
answer_choices.B: hold greater financial appeal for bands than for individual musicians.
answer_choices.C: cause most musicians who use the model to lower the suggested prices of their songs and albums over time.
answer_choices.D: more strongly reflect differences in certain musicians’ popularity than traditional pricing models do.

notes: Observations of orangutans standing on two legs in trees suggest that bipedalism may have originated in tree-dwelling ancestors, not just ground-dwelling ones.
student_goal: Explore an alternate theory of the evolutionary origins of human bipedalism.

answer_choices.A: bipedalism evolved because it was advantageous to a tree-dwelling ancestor of humans.
answer_choices.B: bipedalism must have evolved simultaneously with knuckle-walking and tree-climbing.
answer_choices.C: moving between the ground and the trees would have been difficult without bipedalism.
answer_choices.D: a knuckle-walking human ancestor could have easily moved bipedally in trees.

notes: After copyright expired in 2014, Sherlock Holmes stories became more accessible for adaptations, leading to predictions of an increase in new versions.
student_goal: Understand the impact of copyright expiration on literary adaptations.

answer_choices.A: Doyle’s original stories will become hard to find.
answer_choices.B: people will become more interested in detective stories than they were in the 1800s.
answer_choices.C: producing adaptations will become easier and less expensive.
answer_choices.D: the former copyright holders of Doyle’s estate will return fees they collected.

notes: Pied flycatcher nestlings showed a preference for local bird song dialects. Since song preference affects mate selection, this may influence reproductive patterns.
student_goal: Determine the likely future behavior influenced by early dialect preference in songbirds.

answer_choices.A: F. hypoleuca nestlings’ preference for their own dialect likely disappears as they mature to promote socialization between different F. hypoleuca populations.
answer_choices.B: F. hypoleuca nestlings who show an early preference for their own dialect are likely to receive more food from their caretakers than nestlings who show no preferences among any F. hypoleuca dialects.
answer_choices.C: F. hypoleuca nestlings’ preference for their own dialect likely drives them when they mature to reproduce with other F. hypoleuca from local rather than nonlocal populations.
answer_choices.D: F. hypoleuca nestlings show a preference for both local F. hypoleuca dialects and the songs of other local songbirds over the songs of nonlocal birds of any species.

notes: To test whether holding elected office affects behavior, researchers need control groups. Since elections aren’t random, finding equivalent non-officeholders is hard.
student_goal: Identify a challenge in designing political behavior studies with proper control groups.

answer_choices.A: struggle to find valid data about the behavior of politicians who do not currently hold office.
answer_choices.B: can only conduct valid studies with people who have previously held office rather than people who presently hold office.
answer_choices.C: should select a control group of people who differ from office holders in several significant ways.
answer_choices.D: will find it difficult to identify a group of people who can function as an appropriate control group for their studies.

notes: Researchers tested the effect of physical contact on perceived value. Participants who could touch a mug and toy were willing to pay more than those who could not.
student_goal: Determine the impact of sensory interaction on consumer valuation of products.

answer_choices.A: people who mainly shop online probably spend more money every month than people who mainly shop in person do.
answer_choices.B: in-person shopping may make products seem more valuable than they seem if only viewed online.
answer_choices.C: retailers with in-person and online stores should charge the same price for a given product in both places.
answer_choices.D: online retailers may be able to raise the prices they charge for products that are only available online.

notes: Bertolt Brecht believed theater should provoke intellectual rather than emotional responses. Caryl Churchill’s play Cloud 9 follows this by focusing on patriarchy and colonialism and placing audiences at a distance.
student_goal: Understand how Churchill’s theatrical approach aligns with Brecht’s goals.

answer_choices.A: focus on the characters’ beliefs about social and political issues as revealed by the characters’ actions.
answer_choices.B: reflect on social and political phenomena not directly related to patriarchy and colonialism.
answer_choices.C: recognize pertinent social and political parallels between Germany during Brecht’s time and England at the time when Churchill was writing Cloud 9.
answer_choices.D: be dispassionate as they think critically about the social and political questions raised by the play.

notes: Scholars previously believed the Maya lacked marketplaces due to underestimating ecological diversity in Maya regions. They assumed everyone produced similar crops, removing the need to trade.
student_goal: Understand how ecological assumptions influenced historical interpretations of Maya trade practices.

answer_choices.A: marketplaces likely would not have attracted many traders from outside the regions controlled by the Maya.
answer_choices.B: farming practices would have been largely the same throughout Maya lands even if the crops people produced varied significantly.
answer_choices.C: marketplaces would not have enabled Maya people to acquire many products different from those they already produced.
answer_choices.D: farmers would trade agricultural products only if they had already produced enough to meet their own needs.

notes: Fan cells in the brain are required for forming associative memories and need dopamine to activate. Dopamine is released in response to rewards.
student_goal: Understand how dopamine and rewards affect the formation of associative memories.

answer_choices.A: decrease an individual’s capacity to utilize dopamine.
answer_choices.B: increase an individual’s capacity to recognize differences between unrelated things.
answer_choices.C: increase an individual’s capacity to form associative memories.
answer_choices.D: decrease an individual’s capacity to create fan cells.

notes: Military veterans hold a disproportionately large share of civilian government jobs. One explanation is that veterans are familiar with the bureaucratic structures found in these jobs.
student_goal: Identify the reason veterans might be drawn to civilian government jobs.

answer_choices.A: makes civilian government jobs especially appealing to military veterans.
answer_choices.B: alters the typical relationship between military service and subsequent career preferences.
answer_choices.C: encourages nonveterans applying for civilian government jobs to consider military service instead.
answer_choices.D: increases the number of civilian government jobs that require some amount of military experience to perform.

notes: Mars’s crust was thought to be mostly basalt from cooled magma. But data revealed high silica concentrations, suggesting more complex geological history.
student_goal: Understand what new silica data implies about the formation of Mars’s crust.

answer_choices.A: the information about silica concentrations collected by the spacecraft is likely more reliable than the silica information gleaned from infrared wavelengths detected from Mars’s surface.
answer_choices.B: high silica concentrations on Mars likely formed from a different process than that which formed the crusts of other planets.
answer_choices.C: having a clearer understanding of the composition of Mars’s crust and the processes by which it formed will provide more insight into how Earth’s crust formed.
answer_choices.D: Mars’s crust likely formed as a result of other major geological events in addition to the cooling of a magma ocean.
